trans-unit.source: 1. Naming conventions
trans-unit.target: 1. Naming conventions

trans-unit.source: You should have a good naming convention in place before creating anything in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You should have a good naming convention in place before creating anything in Azure.

trans-unit.source: A naming convention ensures that all the resources have a predictable name, which helps lower the administrative burden associated with managing those resources.
trans-unit.target: A naming convention ensures that all the resources have a predictable name, which helps lower the administrative burden associated with managing those resources.

trans-unit.source: You might choose to follow a specific set of naming conventions defined for your entire organization or for a specific Azure subscription or account.
trans-unit.target: You might choose to follow a specific set of naming conventions defined for your entire organization or for a specific Azure subscription or account.

trans-unit.source: Although it is easy for individuals within organizations to establish implicit rules when working with Azure resources, when a team needs to work on a project on Azure, that model does not scale well.
trans-unit.target: Although it is easy for individuals within organizations to establish implicit rules when working with Azure resources, when a team needs to work on a project on Azure, that model does not scale well.

trans-unit.source: You should agree on a set of naming conventions up front.
trans-unit.target: You should agree on a set of naming conventions up front.

trans-unit.source: There are some considerations regarding naming conventions that cut across the sets of rules that make up those conventions.
trans-unit.target: There are some considerations regarding naming conventions that cut across the sets of rules that make up those conventions.

trans-unit.source: Computer names
trans-unit.target: Computer names

trans-unit.source: When administrators create a virtual machine, Microsoft Azure requires them to provide a virtual machine name of up to 15 characters.
trans-unit.target: When administrators create a virtual machine, Microsoft Azure requires them to provide a virtual machine name of up to 15 characters.

trans-unit.source: Azure uses the virtual machine name as the Azure virtual machine resource name.
trans-unit.target: Azure uses the virtual machine name as the Azure virtual machine resource name.

trans-unit.source: Azure uses the same name as the computer name for the operating system installed in the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Azure uses the same name as the computer name for the operating system installed in the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: However, these names might not always be the same.
trans-unit.target: However, these names might not always be the same.

trans-unit.source: In case a virtual machine is created from a .vhd image file that already contains an operating system, the virtual machine name in Azure can differ from the virtual machine’s operating system computer name.
trans-unit.target: In case a virtual machine is created from a .vhd image file that already contains an operating system, the virtual machine name in Azure can differ from the virtual machine’s operating system computer name.

trans-unit.source: This situation can add a degree of difficulty to virtual machine management, which we therefore do not recommend.
trans-unit.target: This situation can add a degree of difficulty to virtual machine management, which we therefore do not recommend.

trans-unit.source: Assign the Azure virtual machine resource the same name as the computer name that you assign to the operating system of that virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Assign the Azure virtual machine resource the same name as the computer name that you assign to the operating system of that virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that the Azure virtual machine name be the same as the underlying operating system computer name.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that the Azure virtual machine name be the same as the underlying operating system computer name.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, follow the NetBIOS naming rules as described in [Microsoft NetBIOS computer naming conventions](https://support.microsoft.com/kb/188997/).
trans-unit.target: Because of this, follow the NetBIOS naming rules as described in [Microsoft NetBIOS computer naming conventions](https://support.microsoft.com/kb/188997/).

trans-unit.source: 3. Storage
trans-unit.target: 3. Storage

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage is an integral part of many Azure solutions.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage is an integral part of many Azure solutions.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage provides services for storing file data, unstructured data, and messages, and it is also part of the infrastructure supporting virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage provides services for storing file data, unstructured data, and messages, and it is also part of the infrastructure supporting virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: There are two types of storage accounts available from Azure.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of storage accounts available from Azure.

trans-unit.source: A standard storage account gives you access to blob storage (used for storing Azure virtual machine disks), table storage, queue storage, and file storage.
trans-unit.target: A standard storage account gives you access to blob storage (used for storing Azure virtual machine disks), table storage, queue storage, and file storage.

trans-unit.source: Premium storage is designed for high-performance applications, such as SQL Servers in an AlwaysOn cluster, and currently supports Azure virtual machine disks only.
trans-unit.target: Premium storage is designed for high-performance applications, such as SQL Servers in an AlwaysOn cluster, and currently supports Azure virtual machine disks only.

trans-unit.source: Storage accounts are bound to scalability targets.
trans-unit.target: Storage accounts are bound to scalability targets.

trans-unit.source: See [Microsoft Azure subscription and service limits, quotas, and constraints](../azure-subscription-service-limits.md#storage-limits) to become familiar with current Azure storage limits.
trans-unit.target: See [Microsoft Azure subscription and service limits, quotas, and constraints](../azure-subscription-service-limits.md#storage-limits) to become familiar with current Azure storage limits.

trans-unit.source: Also see [Azure storage scalability and performance targets](../storage-scalability-targets.md).
trans-unit.target: Also see [Azure storage scalability and performance targets](../storage-scalability-targets.md).

trans-unit.source: Azure creates virtual machines with an operating system disk, a temporary disk, and zero or more optional data disks.
trans-unit.target: Azure creates virtual machines with an operating system disk, a temporary disk, and zero or more optional data disks.

trans-unit.source: The operating system disk and data disks are Azure page blobs, whereas the temporary disk is stored locally on the node where the machine lives.
trans-unit.target: The operating system disk and data disks are Azure page blobs, whereas the temporary disk is stored locally on the node where the machine lives.

trans-unit.source: This makes the temporary disk unfit for data that must persist during a system recycle, because the machine might silently be migrated from one node to another, losing any data in that disk.
trans-unit.target: This makes the temporary disk unfit for data that must persist during a system recycle, because the machine might silently be migrated from one node to another, losing any data in that disk.

trans-unit.source: Do not store anything on the temporary drive.
trans-unit.target: Do not store anything on the temporary drive.

trans-unit.source: Operating system disks and data disks have a maximum size of 1023 gigabytes (GB) because the maximum size of a blob is 1024 GB and that must contain the metadata (footer) of the VHD file (a GB is 1024<sup>3</sup> bytes).
trans-unit.target: Operating system disks and data disks have a maximum size of 1023 gigabytes (GB) because the maximum size of a blob is 1024 GB and that must contain the metadata (footer) of the VHD file (a GB is 1024<sup>3</sup> bytes).

trans-unit.source: You can implement disk striping in Windows to surpass this limit.
trans-unit.target: You can implement disk striping in Windows to surpass this limit.

trans-unit.source: Striped disks
trans-unit.target: Striped disks

trans-unit.source: Besides providing the ability to create disks larger than 1023 GB, in many instances, using striping for data disks enhances performance by allowing multiple blobs to back the storage for a single volume.
trans-unit.target: Besides providing the ability to create disks larger than 1023 GB, in many instances, using striping for data disks enhances performance by allowing multiple blobs to back the storage for a single volume.

trans-unit.source: With striping, the I/O required to write and read data from a single logical disk proceeds in parallel.
trans-unit.target: With striping, the I/O required to write and read data from a single logical disk proceeds in parallel.

trans-unit.source: Azure imposes limits on the amount of data disks and bandwidth available, depending on the virtual machine size.
trans-unit.target: Azure imposes limits on the amount of data disks and bandwidth available, depending on the virtual machine size.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Sizes for virtual machines](virtual-machines-size-specs.md).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Sizes for virtual machines](virtual-machines-size-specs.md).

trans-unit.target: Use storage striping configuration

trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Storage spaces - designing for performance](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/15200.storage-spaces-designing-for-performance.aspx).

trans-unit.source: 4. Cloud services
trans-unit.target: 4. Cloud services

trans-unit.source: Cloud services are a fundamental building block in Azure service management, both for PaaS and IaaS services.
trans-unit.target: Cloud services are a fundamental building block in Azure service management, both for PaaS and IaaS services.

trans-unit.source: For PaaS, cloud services represent an association of roles whose instances can communicate among each other.
trans-unit.target: For PaaS, cloud services represent an association of roles whose instances can communicate among each other.

trans-unit.source: Cloud services are associated to a public virtual IP (VIP) address and a load balancer, which takes incoming traffic from the Internet and load balances it to the roles configured to receive that traffic.
trans-unit.target: Cloud services are associated to a public virtual IP (VIP) address and a load balancer, which takes incoming traffic from the Internet and load balances it to the roles configured to receive that traffic.

trans-unit.source: In the case of IaaS, cloud services offer similar functionality, although in most cases, the load balancer functionality is used to forward traffic to specific TCP or UDP ports from the Internet to the many virtual machines within that cloud service.
trans-unit.target: In the case of IaaS, cloud services offer similar functionality, although in most cases, the load balancer functionality is used to forward traffic to specific TCP or UDP ports from the Internet to the many virtual machines within that cloud service.

trans-unit.source: 6. Availability sets
trans-unit.target: 6. Availability sets

trans-unit.source: In Azure PaaS, cloud services contain one or more roles that execute application code.
trans-unit.target: In Azure PaaS, cloud services contain one or more roles that execute application code.

trans-unit.source: Roles can have one or more virtual machine instances that the fabric automatically provisions.
trans-unit.target: Roles can have one or more virtual machine instances that the fabric automatically provisions.

trans-unit.source: At any given time, Azure might update the instances in these roles, but because they are part of the same role, Azure knows not to update all at the same time to prevent a service outage for the role.
trans-unit.target: At any given time, Azure might update the instances in these roles, but because they are part of the same role, Azure knows not to update all at the same time to prevent a service outage for the role.

trans-unit.source: In Azure IaaS, the concept of role is not significant, because each IaaS virtual machine represents a role with a single instance.
trans-unit.target: In Azure IaaS, the concept of role is not significant, because each IaaS virtual machine represents a role with a single instance.

trans-unit.source: In order to hint to Azure not to bring down two or more associated machines at the same time (for example, for operating system updates of the node where they reside), the concept of availability sets was introduced.
trans-unit.target: In order to hint to Azure not to bring down two or more associated machines at the same time (for example, for operating system updates of the node where they reside), the concept of availability sets was introduced.

trans-unit.source: An availability set tells Azure not to bring down all the machines in the same availability set at the same time to prevent a service outage.
trans-unit.target: An availability set tells Azure not to bring down all the machines in the same availability set at the same time to prevent a service outage.

trans-unit.source: The virtual machine members of an availability set have a 99.95% uptime service level agreement.
trans-unit.target: The virtual machine members of an availability set have a 99.95% uptime service level agreement.

trans-unit.source: Availability sets must be part of the high-availability planning of the solution.
trans-unit.target: Availability sets must be part of the high-availability planning of the solution.

trans-unit.source: An availability set is defined as the set of virtual machines within a single cloud service that have the same availability set name.
trans-unit.target: An availability set is defined as the set of virtual machines within a single cloud service that have the same availability set name.
